January 27

This came after a Wall Street Journal story that detailed a number of sexual harassment claims against the casino magnate and longtime Trump friend.
Hillary Clinton uses the attention being paid to Trump's first State of the Union to dump out her apology for not firing the aide accused of sexual harassment.

January 23

The day that we learned that special counsel Bob Mueller wants to interview Trump regarding the 2016 election and Russia's attempted interference.
The big headline of the day was Trump's kumbayah meeting with a bipartisan group of congressional lawmakers -- and his pledge to sign a "bill of love."
The White House didn't deny the report in The New York Times but instead chose to emphasize the fact that the President didn't actually fire Mueller.
Stories that would be GIANT news for weeks in another administration wind up being eclipsed by a tweet or an offhanded comment from the President.
And -- the deputy attorney general asks the President not to release the Nunes memo, which allegedly exposes a series of wrongdoing by the FBI.
This was also the day that the saga over why Sen. Rand Paul was mysteriously attacked by a neighbor -- it was a disagreement over landscaping!

January 30

SOTU!
Correction: It was then-acting FBI Director Andrew McCabe who Trump asked about his 2016 vote, not Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein.
Also, another sexual harassment scandal -- this one involving a Pennsylvania Republican House member in a suburban Philadelphia district.
But Trump's tweet suggesting that the FBI was part of a "deep state" conspiracy aimed at undermining his presidency dominated the day.

January 15

The fight over what Trump actually said in that Oval Office immigration meeting on January 11 raged into its fourth day.
But the top Democrat on the Senate Judiciary Committee releasing the transcript of Fusion GPS co-founder Glenn Simpson's testimony?
But the President referring to himself in a tweet as a "very stable genius" is the mathematical equivalent of 100 news stories.
But even an impartial list like this one speaks to just how much news is being created by this White House every damn day.
A massive moment and proof positive that Trump's pledges of bipartisanship from two days earlier were totally meaningless.

January 29

The McCabe resignation was stunning -- even though he had been expected to leave in a few months' time anyway.
With the help of the terrific Brenna Williams , I've cataloged the major news headlines of Trump's first 31 days of 2018.
And the House reauthorizes domestic surveillance just days after Trump seemed to, accidentally, suggest they shouldn't.
But that's not all: Clinton didn't act on reports of sexual harassment by a staffer on her 2008 presidential campaign.
The Supreme Court holds up a plan to re-craft North Carolina's congressional districts before the 2018 election.
And, in other sexual harassment news, Meehan bowed to the inevitable and announced he won't run again in 2018.
The Hatch retirement -- after he was being urged to run for an eighth term -- would normally be a huge story.
The resignation of the CDC director amid controversy and the clearing of Menendez are also giant stories.
That overshadowed the vetoing of Russia sanctions by the White House -- a huge story on any other day.

January 26

The UN ambassador is forced to publicly deny she is having an affair with the President!
We also found out that Mueller and his team had already interviewed Attorney General Jeff Sessions.
(CNN) President Donald Trump demonstrated a unique ability during his first year: He can bend time.

January 4

The book "Fire and Fury" by author Michael Wolff dominated the news early in the month.
(Remember that Trump reportedly asked McCabe who he voted for in a meeting back in May 2017.)
Even Graham, a supporter of Trump, urged the the President to put the controversy behind him.
You are telling me Bannon was more of an opportunist than a Trump loyalist from the jump?
Also, two of the most prominent anti-Trump voices within the GOP spoke out against him.
Bannon pushed out of Breitbart after his anti-Trump comments to author Michael Wolff?
This is by no means a comprehensive list of everything that happened this past month.
Never before have more twists and turns been packed into each day of a presidency.
And a train carrying dozens of House and Senate Republicans crashed into a truck.
Only news that big could push the Guggenheim golden toilet story to second best.
Also, Sheriff Clarke somehow got suspended from Twitter because, well, why not.
Also, "Very Stable Genius" is going to be a hot costume for Halloween 2018.
I've added a few thoughts and bits of context where it makes sense.
